newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austrian Jewish community honours Vranitzky.
newsitem.headline: Austrian Jewish community honours Vranitzky.

text.p: Former Austrian chancellor Franz Vranitzky accepted an award from the nation's Jewish community on Friday in recognition of his efforts to atone for crimes committed by Austrians during the Holocaust.
Vranitzky, who in 1991 became the first chancellor to pay an official visit to Israel, received a Gold Medal dedicated to "Fighters for Justice, Reconciliation and Human Dignity".
"Vranitzky was the first to accept publicly that Austria must bear some guilt for the Shoah. He made a commitment to come to terms with the past," community leader Paul Grosz said.

He thanked the former chancellor for paving the way to last year's Mauerbach auction of Jewish art treasures seized by the Nazis. The auction raised more than 155 million schillings ($13 million) for a Holocaust survivor fund.
"Vranitzky recognised the moral imperative of this sale, which marked a political turning point in Austria," Grosz said.
Receiving the award, Vranitzky said he had always condemned fascism in all its guises. "And that in a country where one can get ahead without exactly opposing fascism," he added.
Vranitzky resigned as chancellor in January and is currently the European envoy to Albania. ($ = 11.89 Austrian Schillings)
